answer: Consuming methanol versus isopropanol leads to different toxicities due to their distinct metabolisms. Methanol is metabolized into formaldehyde and then formic acid, which damages tissues and can lead to end-organ dysfunction, whereas isopropanol is metabolized into acetone, which acts as a central nervous system depressant but does not contribute to the same level of toxicity as formic acid. Therefore, the person consuming methanol could suffer from metabolic acidosis, visual impairments, and potentially life-threatening complications, whereas the individual consuming isopropanol would likely experience longer-lasting central nervous system depressive effects due to acetone but fewer instances of severe metabolic issues unless extremely high quantities were consumed.
